intro: Scleranthus ascriviensis, commonly known as the narrow-leaved thornweed, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and small, greenish-yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in grasslands and along roadsides. Its leaves are narrow and linear, and it produces small, dry fruits that are dispersed by wind. Scleranthus ascriviensis is a hardy species adapted to arid conditions and is often considered a weed in agricultural settings.
